I must say that the wording of the accounts blasted all over the Internet did cause me to draw the wrong conclusion about the CBO report. Unfortunately, in the digital age, once the story gets out there, it can't be recalled. The damage is done. This incident has as much to do with accurate reporting as it does about political manipulations. Even Mr. Krugman has failed to mention that the 2 million job changes are spread out over 10 years. His wording in this piece could give the impression that they will occur all at once.

The Republicans have been manufacturing lies about the healthcare reform with abandon and this misinterpretation of an official non-partisan report will allow them some degree of false legitimacy. I fully expect the wimpy Democratic political machine to treat it the same as all the others and utter the standard. "We don't see it that way."

It is true that many older workers will retire when they can get affordable insurance on their own. That will free up many positions and younger people will fill them.

There is another group that will also benefit greatly and they are younger people that want to start their own businesses. A 35 year old with 3 kids can't take the chance to start a business because the insurance needed to protect the family could cost well over $15K. The ACA will give them an opening. This alone could create up a lot more than 2 million jobs over the next 10 years.

Beautiful and evocative piece. How difficult it is to release the belongings of our loved ones without feeling like we are erasing their very being. My father's Eagle Scout sash with myriad of badges he'd earned, which he kept in his bureau drawer, front and center. His father's tefillin. These things that were treasures to him. There is some guilt about letting go of his prized possessions that I've little connection to. So I keep them.
I have some of my mom's clothes, having kept what I knew I would wear that fit. After she passed, I wore her robe. It was the closest to understanding what being one of Harlow's monkeys was like. I NEEDED that tactile connection. As for my dads many suits, shirts, and shoes (he was an impeccable dresser in his former working life), I was able to part with most of them eventually but it took some years. I didn't want them (or him), to become meaningless. Some of his suits I gave to an NGO that serves refugees who have come here to start new lives. Other suits I donated to my son's high school drama department to be given life again in school plays. I think my dad would be pleased.
I've found a cottage business that sews bags made from men's suit jackets. I will choose one from the few remaining and have a messenger bag made from it.

There is no absolute prescription for a time frame of processing grief and all the "stuff" that goes with it. Thank you for this piece and the comments accompanying it. Grief escapes no one.

"CBO Director Says GOP Is Dead Wrong About ACA Job Loss?"

That means it is even worse than you thought. Awful.
The CBO is not political. I'd rather they stay that way. And Liam Jumper was only making a hypothetical statement.

I don't see where either Clinton is recommending anyone sit out the 2014 elections. First, Hillary has NOT declared and is unlikely to do so until next year IF she does. Second, Democrats of all stripes (Progressives, liberals, plain vanilla) remember all too keenly what happened with earlier midterm elections. Where the split seems to be today is whether to focus on keeping the Senate for Democrats or increasing numbers in the House. Shouldn't be either/or, should be both. State races are every bit as important this year as federal elections in 2016, probably more.

Why didn't we read headlines this past week of, "CBO Director Says GOP Is Dead Wrong About ACA Job Loss?" Why weren't top Democrats shouting that at every media outlet? Bold, startling lies get remembered, become part of what people believe they "know," and are then used to hammer opponents in elections.

Is it because Democratic groups are too busy composing the fund-raising letters I'm now getting regularly? Donors might be more inclined if they saw responses to GOP lies that were more nimble, potent, and sustained.

And now Mancuroc of Rochester, NY tells us, "... Priorities USA says it will be pushing Hillary Clinton for President but sitting out the 2014 midterms."

Really? Clintons didn't learn the reason Obama won the 2008 nomination was because he ran an inclusive campaign?

Clintons don't know you help others win elections in exchange for them helping you when you run for election?

Don't the Clintons realize that if the GOP keeps the House and takes the Senate, the GOP will force a two year legacy of Obama repeatedly having to use his veto pen? Doesn't it occur to them that would be one of the potent rationales used by the GOP in their attempt to place a Republican in the White House?

Political freedom isn't worth much if monied and ideological factions deny working people the elements needed to also attain the economic freedom to enjoy a decent, less anxious, standard of living and the hope that goes with it. That's what's at stake.

Gold emerged as a currency and store of value in the past. It did so independently in many different places around the world. There was no central government spanning Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Middle East that enforced gold usage. What, then, made it emerge? What specific properties made it useful for these purposes?

Something to consider as we ponder why bitcoin is now in the process of emerging.

"Money" is one of the early concepts introduced in a course in economics. Money is an abstraction. But it's an essential part of the economic system that we've developed for ourselves that relies on it.

Money is "a means of exchange" and "a store of value." With Bitcoin, the means of exchange I understand. But a "store of value," Bitcoin?

"Value" comes largely from trust. Governmental central banks that issue currencies, the government or governments that control the central banks in effect underwrite the value of the issued currency. The government or governments provide the "trust" in the currency. If you think that's not true, then look around you and look at history, shaky governments don't issue trusted currencies.

Bitcoin is something completely different. As near as I can tell, it doesn't pin its value against a specific currency. Its users seem to consider it a separate, independent currency.

So what's backing Bitcoin up? So far as I can tell, it's smoke and mirrors thus making it a playing field for scam artists, dreamers and a host of others.

The ACA has the effect of giving bargaining power to workers.

Workers no longer have to have employment to have insurance. That reduces the employer's leverage.

I've repeatedly have taken the position, and still do, that the American system is based upon only one principle: free contract. In that system, bargaining power is everything. What you earn is a function of it. The Rich/Republican know this. The concentration in wealth over the last 40 years is the result of the systematic attack, by the rich, against the agencies of other groups bargaining power, the most obvious cases were unions for workers, ACORN for the very poor, the cost and quality of education for the aspiring middle class.

The fire of the Republican response to the ACA makes no sense on the surface: it is, after all, their idea, their plan. However, it does make sense from the perspective of bargaining power analysis. Huge swings in earnings occur at marginal shifts in bargaining power. The Rich, the republicans know that. That's why they are rich.

Just a subtle shift in bargaining power is going to cause a disproportional shift in the distribution of earnings from the 1% to the 99%. If you could add 2.5 million jobs to the economy tomorrow, we'd be approaching full employment and it would show up in earnings and economic security to the 99%. In time hopefully we'll see this.

So in my mind the effect on bargaining power is the real explanation for Republican mendacity towards their own plan.

Wendell, again, we are 37 days in.

I can see where this is going; people working less, to get the subsidy. Multiply this by hundreds of thousands if not millions of people and what do you get; more people on the govt. teat.

My specifics in the premium and deductible increase?

I am 59 years old, prior to Obamacare had a catastrophic policy. The premium $320/month. $3,500 deductible, $5,500 max OOP.

With Obamacare, $680/month premium, and $6,000 deductible.

I am a single person, making $50,000 no subsidies for me.

The silver lining I have no insurance at all, now. But it is OK. I get sick, I'll just sign up then.

Not with the exchanges, they have strict enrollment periods. But with an insurance company outside the exchanges. There are plenty of those. With those companies I can sign up anytime. And under Obamacare they can not refuse me.

This will never work. This Obamacare. The basic structure is flawed.

There are 106 schools that claim HBCU status. Southern University has the lowest graduation rate in the country - 8% over six years. It is time for blacks to stop supporting failing HBCUs that are little more than citadels for sinecures. We should focus the money on only the best HBCUs. Howard would easily make that cut. Am I being cold? Try this test: 1) Wiki "List of of HBCUs." 2) Enter any school in www.collegeresults.org. 3) Look at the 6 year graduation rate. You'll be 'shocked, shocked' to find that most are under 30%.

True.  In addition, those who freely choose to reduce their hours tend to do so because they have adequate additional sources of income, so it does not effect the economy anywhere nearly as much as when a person is let go by their employer and my find themselves in dire financial circumstances and not able to purchase basic necessities.  So these voluntary chosen reduced hours do not have the same impact, yet they open up jobs for those who do need the work.  There potentially may be a net positive effect here that is being missed.

Young Man, the complaints you lodge concerning your experience as a student at an HBCU are, in fact, no different than the complaints I have had from students at white institutions, including the one where I teach: High tuition, "difficult" or "indifferent" faculty, not enough diversity, lack of resources, HIGH DEBT upon graduation. None of this has anything to do with "pro-black" and everything to do with changing economics and the difficulties in delivering quality education for today's students. Many colleges - both white and HBCUs - are grappling with the need to "change with the times." I graduated from Howard in 1967. My years there were among the happiest four years in my life; my academic preparation allowed me to compete at the highest levels of my profession. And we students complained, EVERY DAY, about arcane and old-fashioned rules, the school's refusal to change with the times, the rising tuition, lack of resources, and we never felt we received adequate counseling, even as some of us prepared to go to Ivy League schools for Graduate study, or enter into the business world having just been recruited by corporate "head-hunters." It is fascinating to see that, 40 years later, the complaints seem to be the same. In the end, the HBCUs will survive because they must. They will grow and they will improve. They did in my day. They will in yours.

Internship structure and support certainly did not arrive on a silver tray, but it most certainly was there. I found faculty, advisors and a far reaching system of professional preparation readily and eagerly available to me, so long as I asked. How like the real world!

Love the frankness of the article. It is rather ironic that many students would want to say they had a wonderful experience, but these HBCU's have serious issues. Let put out, first they are expensive, the staff and faculty act as if they are doing you a favor, students graduate with more debt than they can pay back, poor structuring of internships experiences, not enough research or publications and the support level are almost non-existent, just to name a few. For the record I attended one, and this was my experience. When students graduate from these schools they often are in no position to give back because they owe SALLIEMAE!!! As it relates to diversification, they need to do so and change with the times. The world is flat and though there are issues of de-facto segregation, but some of these schools need to wake up and change with the time. This pro-black mentality is not going to work in a global economy.
Clark Atlanta, Morehouse, Howard, need to create a better experience and find ways to lower the debt undergraduate and graduate students graduate with so they can give money back when they graduate. In addition, the experience at some of these schools is like attending high school. Some of faculty's behavior is synonymous with power rather than uplifting the students who attend them. Their mode of transactional leadership needs revision and should be inclusive of transformation leadership, rather then the nepotistic culture often spewed.

What sorts of jobs would you create for someone who used to be a machinist or a seamstress or work in a tire plant? And who should be creating them? Republicans say if we just reduce taxes on corporations to infinitesimal size then suddenly companies will be willing to create millions of jobs. Well, we've already reduced and reduced and reduced tax rates and where are the jobs? The dot.com companies, for example, employ almost no one in comparison to the work force manufacturers used to need, and you don't go from being a machinist to a software developer over a weekend. We got rid of all kinds of jobs that used to employ tens of millions and never thought, with this rapid change, what those people were going to do when they became as essential to 21st century life as blacksmiths became in the 20th century. We still seem to have no idea. Absent one, govt either provides new jobs or long-term unemployment benefits. It is now doing neither.

Only those of us who are unemployed can truly know the terror of having no job, no unemployment benefits and no health insurance. I was laid-off 7 months ago after my company down-sized. I worked there 10 years. I can assure those of you who are blaming the victim, that none of us were getting rich receiving unemployment. You receive about half of what your previous income was, and I for one was barely making ends meet. Now of course with no unemployment extension I am on the verge of losing everything. All I do everyday is look for work and worry. I wish I could think about the elections in the fall, or moving to another state as someone suggested, but right now all I can think about is my mortgage being due on the 15th. I won't forget how we are being treated and how little compassion some people have for us. You can't begin to know our depression, helplessness, and hopelessness. I will pray for all of us, I am living this nightmare too.
